bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Thomas M. England, August 4, 1942

div1.p: Hench requests that England contact him as he would like to pose some questions regarding the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Thomas M. England, August 4, 1942
div1.opener:
August 4, 1942
Major Thomas M. England
Medical Administrative Corps
Surgeon's Office; 5th Corps Area
Columbus, Ohio
My dear Major England:
div1.p:
For some time now I have been making a
medical-historical study of the conquest of yellow fever.
I have visited Mr. Moran in Cuba twice, Mr. Kissinger,
the Reed family and Gen. Kean in Washington, Gen. Truby
(now in San Francisco), Dr. Cooke in Lexington, Virginia
and others including Mr. Andrus in Camden and Gust Lambert
in Chicago, I have corresponded with the Lazear family,
Mrs. Roger Post Ames, Mr. Hanberry and many others. I
did not obtain your address until recently and am glad
indeed to know where you are.

Permit me to send you by separate post
some items which I think will interest you. I would appre-
ciate the privilege of hearing from you, and later, if you
will permit, I'd like to write down a few questions the
answers of which I am most anxious to have.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:as
Sent separately:
1. The Mile Post
2. Washington and Jefferson clipping
3. Rochester Post Bulletin, Oct. 28, 1940
4. “Yellow Jack” in True Comics
5. Hygeia article
